topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Shweta Shrivastava, her background (Waymo, Nauto, AWS, Cisco), and what the episode will cover about building self-driving products and teams.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Vanta (security compliance automation) and Public.com (treasury accounts).

topics.title: Shweta’s scope at Waymo
topics.summary: Shweta explains her org’s three areas: onboard autonomy software (behavior/trajectory), simulation/validation tooling, and scaling the ride-hailing business.

topics.title: Lenny’s Waymo ride experience in SF
topics.summary: Lenny recounts taking a driverless Waymo ride in rainy San Francisco and how quickly the experience felt normal, setting context for product questions.

topics.title: Car “body language” and social driving norms
topics.summary: They discuss how Waymo learns human-like driving cues (e.g., inching to merge) using human driving data and deep learning, including interpreting intent and adapting to local social norms.

topics.title: How Waymo PM differs from software PM
topics.summary: Shweta contrasts Waymo with traditional software: deeper technical complexity, higher ambiguity, long time horizons, mission-driven culture, and a much higher MVP safety bar.

topics.title: Designing trust in fully driverless rides
topics.summary: Shweta explains Waymo’s design philosophy for credibility and predictability, why rides feel “uneventful” after minutes, and how transparency/support features build rider trust.

topics.title: Small behavior details that increase comfort
topics.summary: They cover how many small choices create trust, including strict speed-limit adherence and tuning behavior (e.g., slowing on downhill slopes) to match human expectations.

topics.title: Waymo KPIs: commercial, ops, and driving performance
topics.summary: Shweta outlines metric categories: ride-hailing funnel/commercial and operational costs, plus driver performance metrics spanning safety, compliance, progress, and minimizing stops/strands.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Element (electrolyte drink mix).

topics.title: L4 vs L5 autonomy and remaining blockers
topics.summary: Shweta explains autonomy levels, argues L4 deployments can fulfill most needs without L5, and notes remaining capability gaps like robust snow driving.

topics.title: Sustaining long-term investor buy-in
topics.summary: They discuss maintaining support for long-horizon bets by showing meaningful progress—especially commercial deployment—while staying focused on real customer value and business fundamentals.

topics.title: Cross-company product and team lessons
topics.summary: Shweta shares core PM principles: work backwards from customer problems (e.g., Amazon PR/FAQ), be explicit about what not to build, and disrupt yourself to avoid the innovator’s dilemma (example: Amazon Honeycode).

topics.title: Underrated PM skills: listening, empathy, assumptions
topics.summary: They explore why listening and empathy are hard but essential, how they’re developed through varied environments, and why challenging your own assumptions is key to real listening.

topics.title: Getting promoted: focus on impact, not optics
topics.summary: Shweta advises that promotions follow visible business impact, not maneuvering; communicate ambition, seek stretching projects, and prioritize outcomes over self-optimization.

topics.title: Where Waymo operates and how to try it
topics.summary: Shweta shares current availability (Phoenix, San Francisco), expansion plans for LA, and how riders can download the app and provide feedback.

topics.title: Lightning round and closing
topics.summary: Lightning round covers book recommendations, favorite media, interview question, a desired foldable e-bike, a “rule of seven” for ending email threads, and a Waymo ride tip; they close with where to find Shweta and how listeners can help.
